OPIOIDS

Opioids are analgesics derived from the poppy plant Papaver Somniferum. Opioids can be classified as full opioid agonist (which are further classified as opium alkaloid, semi-synthetic opioid agonists, and synthetic opioid agonists), partial opioid agonist, or mixed opioid agonist-antagonist (refer to the table below):

Opium alkaloids Semisynthetic opioid agonists Synthetic opioid agonists

There is general confusion on the use of the terms opiates and opioids. The term opiate refers to naturally-derived opium derivatives, while the term opioid refers to (semi) synthetic compounds with pharmacological effects similar to opium.

All opioids have similar mechanisms of action but differ in the rate, extent, and duration of the analgesic effect; the occurrence of adverse effects; and the risk of addiction. The pharmacological effects of opioid agonists are mediated by activation of opioid receptors. These opioid receptors are divided into at least four subtypes: mu (µ), kappa (κ), delta (δ) and sigma (σ). All opioid agonists have a high affinity for the mu-receptors, varying activity for beta- and delta-receptors, and substantially no effect on the sigma-receptors.Below is a summary of phamacological effects following stimulation of these receptors.

Opioid receptors
Mu Kappa Delta Sigma
  • Supraspinal analgesia
  • Respiratory depression
  • Euphoria
  • Physical dependence
  • Spinal analgesia
  • Miosis
  • Sedation
  • Affective behavior
  • Analgesia
  • Dysphoria
  • Hallucination
  • Respiratory stimulation
  • Central vasomotor stimulation

Street names of commonly-abused opioids include:

  • Mainlining (commonly-used combination of heroin and cocaine)
  • China White (alpha- or 3-methyl-fentanyl)
  • 3s and 4s (codeine)
  • Loads, packs (codeine and glutethimide)
  • H, horse, junk, smack (heroin)
  • Speedball (heroin, amphetamine or cocaine)
  • Dolly (methadone)
  • M, Emma (morphine)
  • Perks (oxycodone)
  • Blues (oxymorphone)
  • Ts and blues (pentazocine and tripelennamine)

In the Netherlands, the heroin content of “street heroin” ranges from 20% to 80%. Heroin is often abused in combination with various substances such as caffeine, acetaminophen, sugars, papaverine, noscapine, phenobarbital, diazepam, strychnine, quinine, cocaine, amphetamine, phenacetin, indomethacin, and gluthetimide.
